stem: A client is using Peritoneal Dialysis (PD) at home. Based on the documentation in the Peritoneal Effluent & Metabolic Log, which finding is the most definitive indicator that the client has developed peritonitis?

tabs.title: Effluent Analysis
tabs.content:
TestResultCritical Value
Effluent WBC Count1,200 / mm³> 100 / mm³
Neutrophil Count82%> 50%
Gram StainGram Positive OrganismsPresence of bacteria

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: Current: Client reports abdominal 'stiffening' and 8/10 pain. Rebound tenderness noted. Temperature 101.4°F. Client states: 'I can't see the newsprint through the drain bag anymore.'

options.text: The cloudy, opaque appearance of the peritoneal effluent
The effluent WBC count of 1,200 / mm³
The patient's report of 8/10 abdominal pain

rationale.correct: While the cloudy appearance (a1) is the first *visual* cue for the patient, the **effluent WBC count of 1,200 (a2)** is the most definitive clinical indicator of peritonitis in a PD patient. A WBC count > 100 with > 50% neutrophils in the dialysate is diagnostic of infection. The cloudy appearance is actually caused by the accumulation of these white blood cells and bacteria in the fluid.
clinicalPearls: PD effluent should be **Clear/Straw-colored** (you should be able to read a newspaper through the bag).
Blood-tinged effluent is normal in menstruating women or right after catheter placement; cloudy is NEVER normal.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing 'Cloudy appearance' (a1) because it's the most common answer.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In 'Analyze Cues' questions, prioritize the objective **laboratory confirmation** over the subjective/visual finding if both are present. WBC count is the 'gold standard' for peritonitis diagnosis.

mnemonic.title: PD Clear
mnemonic.expansion: Clear is Good. Cloudy is Bad. White in the bag makes the nurse sad.
